link.script:
{"url":"https://www.dscdo.org","name":"Detroit Shoreway","description":"
Detroit Shoreway Community Development Organization is a non-profit 501(c)3 community development corporation, founded in 1973 to catalyze development in Cleveland\u2019s Detroit Shoreway neighborhood.","image":"//static1.squarespace.com/static/5a906218cef372c749c9dae7/t/5addfabc03ce64b1e432accf/1588181841071/","@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"WebSite"}

{"legalName":"Detroit Shoreway Community Deveopment Organization","address":"6516 Detroit Avenue\nCleveland, OH, 44102\nUnited States","email":"","telephone":"2169618830","sameAs":[],"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"Organization"}

{"address":"6516 Detroit Avenue\nCleveland, OH, 44102\nUnited States","image":"https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5a906218cef372c749c9dae7/t/5addfabc03ce64b1e432accf/1588181841071/","name":"Detroit Shoreway Community Deveopment Organization","openingHours":"Mo 08:00-17:00, Tu 08:00-17:00, We 08:00-17:00, Th 08:00-17:00, Fr 08:00-17:00, , ","@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness"}

div.p: Detroit Shoreway Community Development Organization and Cudell Improvement, Inc. have compiled this list of nearby providers. This list was last updated April 28, 2020, at 3:00pm, but all items are subject to change. For updated information and additional resources, contact providers directly or call 211. You can also request or offer assistance with Cleveland Pandemic Response, a volunteer mutual aid group.

Follow the recommendations of the Centers for Disease Control: Stay at home and avoid close contact with others (within about 6 feet). Clean your hands often with soap and water or with hand sanitizer. Find the latest recommendations at cdc.gov/coronavirus. For dealing with anxiety during this time, see these ODH recommendations.

If you have symptoms (fever, cough, sore throat, headache, chills, tiredness, loss of taste/smell, difficulty breathing), stay at home. Call MetroHealth’s hotline at (440) 592-6843 for an assessment or contact your physician. You can schedule a virtual appointment if you have a physician at Cleveland Clinic or University Hospitals.
Meals will be packaged and distributed to go until further notice. You can also view a community-organized map of free meals and food distributions here.

Every Weekday during school closure, 11:30am-1pm – Cleveland Metropolitan School District is providing 2 take-home meals for any children 18 and younger and accompanying adults. (View map of CMSD locations.)

li.p: Free shuttles at 11am from: Joseph M. Gallagher School (6601 Franklin Blvd), Marion C. Seltzer (1468 W 98th St). Student RTA passes are also still valid.

div.p: Every Weekday at 11am-1pm, every Saturday & Sunday at 12-2pm – Urban Community School (4909 Lorain Ave) | (216) 939-8330
Every Weekday at 9am and 12pm, every Saturday at 9am and 4:30pm – West Side Catholic Center (3135 Lorain Ave) | (216) 631-4741
Every Weekday at 4-5pm, every Saturday at 12-1pm - Children’s Hunger Alliance is providing 2 meals for children 18 and younger at most City Recreation Centers.

li.p: Michael J. Zone Recreation Center (6301 Lorain Ave) | (216) 664-3373

div.p: Every Weekday at 11:30am-12pm and 5:30-6pm – St. Herman House (4410 Franklin Blvd) | (216) 961-3806
Every Monday during school closure, 12pm-2pm – Banter (7320 Detroit Ave) | (216) 801-0305
Every Tuesday through Thursday at 5:30pm – St. Patrick’s Church (3602 Bridge Ave) | (216) 631-6872
Every Wednesday, 6-6:45pm – St. Luke’s Episcopal Church (1349 West 78th St) | (216) 631-2841
Every Thursday during school closure, 11am-2pm – Gypsy Beans (6425 Detroit Ave) | (216) 939-9009
Every Thursday, 12pm - Calvary Reformed Church (1918 W 65th St) | (216) 961-4271
Every 3rd Friday, 5:30pm - Calvary Reformed Church (1918 W 65th St) | (216) 961-4271
Every 1st Tuesday, 2nd Thursday, and 4th Monday at 5pm – Church of the Ascension at east door (13216 Detroit Ave, Lakewood) | (216) 521-8727

Emergency food assistance may also be available in the interim. Call the Greater Cleveland Food Bank Help Center at (216) 738-2067 or contact the providers below directly. You can also view a community-organized map of free meals and food distributions here.
Every Tuesday through Friday, 10-11:30am – St. Paul’s Community UCC (4427 Franklin Blvd) | (216) 651-6250
Every Wednesday & Friday, 10am-2pm – St. Patrick’s Church (3602 Bridge Ave) | (216) 631-6872
Every 1st Friday, 4-5pm – Marion C. Seltzer School (1468 W 98th St) | (216) 838-6550
Every 1st Saturday, 9:30am-12pm – Calvary Reformed Church (1918 W 65th St) | (216) 961-4271
Every 2nd & 4th Monday, 5-7pm – St. Luke’s Episcopal Church (1349 West 78th St) | Drive-thru pick-up only, (216) 631-2841
Every 3rd Saturday, 10am-12pm – New Beginnings Ministry (2060 W 65th St) | (216) 916-9270
Every 4th Wednesday, 9am-12pm – May Dugan Center (4115 Bridge Avenue) - Drive-thru pick-up only or call (216) 631-5800 x300 to make other arrangements
Cleveland Muslim Volunteers is providing free groceries and delivery (typically on Saturdays) to anyone in need (of any faith or background). Please fill out this form or call (216) 532-1775.

If you are ordering delivery or take-out food during this closure, please support our local businesses. See dscdo.org/food for ordering food in the Detroit Shoreway, Cudell and Edgewater neighborhoods.

The CARES Act will provide “Economic Impact Payments” in April of up to $1,200 per adult for individuals whose income was less than $99,000 and $500 per child under 17 years old. The payments will be automatic for most people, but if you did not file taxes in 2018 or 2019 or are an SSI/SSDI recipient who needs to claim child dependents, visit this IRS page now.

If you are unemployed, self-employed, or contracted, apply for benefits at unemployment.ohio.gov or call (877) 644-6562. Unemployment benefits will also be available for eligible individuals who are requested by a medical professional, local health authority, or employer to be isolated or quarantined as a consequence of COVID-19, even if they are not actually diagnosed with COVID-19. In addition, the waiting period for eligible Ohioans to receive unemployment benefits will be waived. See this FAQ list at cleveland.com.
To apply for healthcare, childcare, food, and cash benefits, visit benefits.ohio.gov or call 1 (844) 640-6446.

Limited emergency assistance vouchers for food, supplies, and housing may be available from Cuyahoga Job and Family Services for residents at or below 200% of federal poverty guidelines. Call 211 or visit bit.ly/ccprc for guidelines and application.
If you are looking for a job, find employers currently hiring at ohiomeansjobs.com.

Spectrum is offering free broadband and Wi-Fi access for 60 days to households with K-12 and/or college students who do not already have a Spectrum broadband subscription and at any service level up to 100 Mbps. To enroll, call 1 (844) 488-8395. Installation fees will be waived for new student households.

Comcast is offering two free months of internet service to all qualified, low-income households. You may cancel at any time or continue the service at $9.95 per month. To enroll, call 1 (855) 846-8376 or visit internetessentials.com.

AT&T is offering two free months of internet service to limited income households who participate in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program and apply by April 30. After two months, the service continues at $5 or $10 per month, depending on plan speed. Apply by calling 1 (855) 220-5211 or visiting att.com/access.
Emergency, interest-free loans up to $1,500 may be available from HFLA of Northeast Ohio for anyone impacted by COVID-19. Apply at interestfree.org or call (216) 378-9042.
If you are a bartender or work in the beverage industry, check out this specific grant program: usbgfoundation.org/beap
The City of Cleveland has ended utility cut-offs during the crisis. Contact your utility provider if necessary:

We’ve made a list of examples of ways to support small businesses and nonprofits in the Detroit Shoreway, Cudell and Edgewater neighborhoods during this time. You can also view our map/list of shops and organizations and reach out to places you love to ask how best to help.
If you are a business owner looking for assistance, please see this up-to-date resources list or email us.
For children at home from school, please see Cleveland Metropolitan School District’s K-12 learning resources. For other assistance from CMSD, call 216-838-0000.

WVIZ/PBS ideastream’s weekday TV programs are now tailored for children ages 3 to 8 (7-9am) and ages 9 and older (9am-6pm). Watch over-the-air on channel 25.1 or through your local cable/satellite provider.

Local teaching artists from Talespinner Children’s Theatre are posting theater activities, games and more. Scholastic Learn at Home has day-to-day educational projects, and PBS posted this guide: How to Talk to Your Kids About Coronavirus. For even more online resources, see these lists from We Are Teachers and How to Homeschool for Free.
All children from birth to age 5 can receive a free book mailed to them each month from Dolly Parton’s Imagination Library. Sign up here.
Rite Aid (6512 Franklin Blvd) – Call (216) 281-6100
CVS – Visit cvs.com or call your local CVS:
Walgreens (11701 Detroit Ave) – Visit walgreens.com, text JoinRX to 21525, or call (216) 227-0819
Please consult the State of Ohio’s Stay at Home order before any volunteer activity, and continue following the CDC’s health guidelines. Contact the providers below directly to volunteer.

li.p: Children’s Hunger Alliance - volunteers to distribute food on weekdays, 4-5pm, and Saturdays, 12-1pm
Michael J. Zone Recreation Center (6301 Lorain Ave) - (216) 664-4137
St. Luke’s Episcopal Church (1349 West 78th St) - volunteers to set up and distribute food on 2nd and 4th Mondays, 2:30-7pm - (216) 631-2841
Gypsy Beans (6425 Detroit Ave) - volunteers to distribute food on Thursdays, 10am-2:30pm - (216) 939-9009
May Dugan Center (4115 Bridge Ave) - volunteers to set up and distribute food pantry every 4th Wednesday, 8:30am-12pm and 12-3pm - (216) 261-4600

div.p: If you have a printer, you may also print this page and safely share it with a neighbor who might need resources. You can also print this postcard to offer your assistance to a neighbor. Remember to wash your hands and avoid physical contact.
If you can’t safely volunteer right now, check out our examples of ways to support small businesses and nonprofits.
If you are looking for local childcare options, call Starting Point’s hotline, (216) 575-0061, during regular business hours for up-to-date, certified providers, or view a map of providers here.

Effective beginning April 12: If you need to make an essential trip, please note that RTA will temporarily reduce service by about 15% system-wide, including the Red Line and the 22, 25, 26, 55 and 78 bus lines. Routes will not change, but trains and buses will run less frequently.
